unnormalised: ## Wildlife Conservation: Why should you care? (and what can you do?)
normalised: ## Wildlife Conservation: Why should you care? (and what can you do?)

unnormalised: Wildlife conservation is crucial for the health of our planet, and it directly impacts us, even if we live far from forests or national parks. India, with its rich biodiversity ranging from the snow leopards of the Himalayas to the Bengal tigers of the Sunderbans, has a special responsibility in this area.
normalised: Wildlife conservation is crucial for the health of our planet, and it directly impacts us, even if we live far from forests or national parks. India, with its rich biodiversity ranging from the snow leopards of the Himalayas to the Bengal tigers of the Sunderbans, has a special responsibility in this area.

unnormalised: But why bother? Well, healthy ecosystems provide vital services. Forests help regulate rainfall (critical for agriculture, especially considering the monsoon's importance in India) and clean our air. Endangered species like the Indian vulture play a vital role in disease control by scavenging carcasses. Losing them can have devastating consequences.

unnormalised: Think about it: The Sunderbans mangrove forests protect coastal communities from cyclones, saving countless lives and billions of Rs. in damages each year. When we destroy these habitats, we increase our vulnerability.
normalised: Think about it: The Sunderbans mangrove forests protect coastal communities from cyclones, saving countless lives and billions of rupees in damages each year. When we destroy these habitats, we increase our vulnerability.

unnormalised: What can you do? A lot! Start by educating yourself. Learn about the flora and fauna native to your region. Support organizations like the Wildlife Institute of India or Bombay Natural History Society that are actively involved in conservation efforts. Even small changes in your lifestyle can make a difference. Reduce your consumption, support sustainable businesses, and avoid products made from endangered species.

unnormalised: During Onam, instead of buying imported exotic fruits, choose locally grown options that support local farmers and reduce the environmental impact of transportation. Every little action counts towards a healthier planet for us all.
